mentions.context: ProvSQL is a tool integrated into PostgreSQL that can perform provenance (lineage) computation in various semir- ings.
ProvSQL [31] was used to capture the provenance.

CNF Proxy is substantially faster than its competitors: in most cases CNF Proxy completes in few milliseconds and 4 seconds in the worst case, whereas Monte Carlo and Kernel SHAP median execution time for circuits with 101-200 distinct input facts are 59 and 62 seconds respectively and may take up to 1,539 seconds.
CNF Proxy performs the best, and its quality remains steady regardless of the number of facts in the provenance expression.

Our system is implemented in Python 3.6 and using the PostgreSQL 11.10 database engine, and the experiments were performed on a Linux Debian 14.04 machine with 1TB of RAM and an Intel(R) Xeon(R) Gold 6252 CPU @ 2.10GHz processor.
Note that CNF Proxy is much faster then the other methods, while still being superior in terms of ranking (nDCG and Precision@k).
In Line 1, CNF Proxy counts the number 𝑛 of clauses of 𝜑, and in Line 2 it initializes the contribution of every variable of 𝜑 to zero.
Similarly, CNF Proxy outperforms Monte Carlo and Kernel SHAP in terms of Precision@k for 𝑘 ∈ {1, 3, 5}.
Recall that CNF Proxy does not rely on sampling, and so it remains constant throughout the different budgets.
Observe that CNF Proxy runs in linear time in the size of 𝜑 (which itself, being the Tseytin transformation of the provenance circuit 𝐶 ′ from Figure 3, is linear in 𝐶 ′ ).
For example, CNF Proxy's median (resp., mean) Precision@10 are 1.0 (resp., 0.9688), while Kernel SHAP reaches 1.0 (resp., 0.9611) with 50 samples per fact.
Note that CNF Proxy is much faster then the other methods, while still being superior in terms of ranking (nDCG and Precision@k).

At a high level, CNF Proxy is based on the observation that hav- ing a high Shapley score is correlated (albeit in a complex manner) with (1) appearing many times in the provenance and (2) having few "alternatives," that is, facts that could compensate for the ab- sence of the given fact.
In our case, we use ProvSQL as follows: we feed it the database 𝐷, query 𝑞( x) and tuple t, and ProvSQL computes Lin(𝑞 [ x/ t], 𝐷) as a Boolean circuit, called 𝐶 in Figure 3.
Unfortunately, every knowl- edge compiler that we are aware of takes as input Boolean formulas in conjunctive normal form (CNF), and not arbitrary Boolean cir- cuits.

To measure quality, we use CNF Proxy to rank the input tuples, and compared the obtained ranked lists to ranking by actual Shapley values (in cases where exact computation has succeeded), using the standard measures of nDCG and Precision@k.

In this section we propose CNF Proxy, a heuristic solution that is very efficient, and we will experimentally show that the ranking of facts based on CNF Proxy tends to match the ranking based on the exact Shapley values.

Our system is implemented in Python 3.6 and using the PostgreSQL 11.10 database engine, and the experiments were performed on a Linux Debian 14.04 machine with 1TB of RAM and an Intel(R) Xeon(R) Gold 6252 CPU @ 2.10GHz processor.
We compare three algorithms: CNF Proxy (Section 5) and two existing baselines: Monte Carlo, and Kernel SHAP.

• We present a novel heuristic, CNF Proxy, that is fast yet inex- act, and is practically effective if we are interested in ranking input facts by their contribution rather than computing exact Shapley values (Section 5).
Next, we present the details of CNF Proxy.
For example, with 1-10 facts the CNF Proxy median (resp., mean) nDCG is 1.0 (resp., 0.9999), and with 201-400 facts it is 0.9977 (resp., 0.9924).
By contrast, our inexact solution CNF Proxy is extremely fast even for these hard cases -it typically terminates in a few milliseconds with the worst observed case (an outlier) being 4 seconds.
ProvSQL is a tool integrated into PostgreSQL that can perform provenance (lineage) computation in various semir- ings.

Indeed, the median (resp., mean) nDCG of CNF Proxy is 1.0 (resp., 0.9989), while Kernel SHAP requires 50 samples per fact to get a median (resp., mean) nDCG of 1.0 (resp., 0.9986); as previ- ously noted such budget leads to slower execution than that of the exact computation.
For knowledge compilation we have used the c2d compiler [9, 10].

Algorithm 2 then describes the operation of CNF Proxy, com-
puting Shapley values of 𝜑 according to Lemma 5.2.

We saw in Section 6.2 that the inexact method CNF Proxy is very efficient and that the ranking of tuples based on CNF Proxy is typically close to the ranking obtained based on the real Shapley values.

The solution that we propose to this end is termed CNF Proxy; it is based on a transformation of the provenance to Conjunctive Normal Form (CNF) and using it to compute proxy values intuitively based on (1) the number of clauses in which a variable occur and (2) its alternatives in each clause.
If we have reached the timeout, resort to executing CNF Proxy and rank the facts based on the obtained values.
We use two existing tools to help us with this task: ProvSQL [31] and the knowledge compiler c2d [10].

Our system is implemented in Python 3.6 and using the PostgreSQL 11.10 database engine, and the experiments were performed on a Linux Debian 14.04 machine with 1TB of RAM and an Intel(R) Xeon(R) Gold 6252 CPU @ 2.10GHz processor.

Experimental evidence shows that the ranking obtained via CNF Proxy is both much faster to compute and more accurate (in terms of nDCG and Precision@k, measured in cases where exact computation does succeed, and so we have the ground truth) than the alternative of only using sampling to approximate the actual Shapley values.
In terms of nDCG, all methods achieve rather high scores, but CNF Proxy per- forms best.
Figure 7 depicts the perfor- mance of Monte Carlo, Kernel SHAP, and CNF Proxy as a function of the number of facts in the provenance expression.
In terms of identifying the top influential facts (i.e., Precision@k), CNF Proxy also outperforms the other methods.

CNF Proxy is substantially faster than its competitors: in most cases CNF Proxy completes in few milliseconds and 4 seconds in the worst case, whereas Monte Carlo and Kernel SHAP median execution time for circuits with 101-200 distinct input facts are 59 and 62 seconds respectively and may take up to 1,539 seconds.
When it does not, we propose an alternative of ranking facts according to CNF Proxy values, which typically only takes several milliseconds (up to 4 seconds for an outlier case).
As explained above, ranking of facts is indeed the use case we recommend for CNF Proxy.
Otherwise, we terminate the exact computation and execute the inexact method CNF Proxy, returning only a ranking of input tuples rather than their Shapley values.
First, we have measured (in the column "Execution time") the execution time in PostgreSQL, which includes provenance generation for every out- put tuple using ProvSQL.
It is worth mentioning that also when looking at nDCG@k for 𝑘 ∈ {1, 3, 5, 10}, CNF Proxy performs better than Monte Carlo and Kernel SHAP, even when allowing a budget of 50 samples per fact.
As explained above, ranking of facts is indeed the use case we recommend for CNF Proxy.

The execution times of Monte Carlo and Kernel SHAP are rather similar, while the CNF Proxy method (which does not rely on sampling) is substantially faster, with a median of 0.72 milliseconds and a mean of 2.06 mil- liseconds for a single query output.
Here again, Figure 7f zooms in on the worst case and again shows the superiority of CNF Proxy.
We have then transformed each provenance expression into a d-DNNF structure using the c2d [9, 10] knowledge compiler.
We use two existing tools to help us with this task: ProvSQL [31] and the knowledge compiler c2d [10].
In our case, we use ProvSQL as follows: we feed it the database 𝐷, query 𝑞( x) and tuple t, and ProvSQL computes Lin(𝑞 [ x/ t], 𝐷) as a Boolean circuit, called 𝐶 in Figure 3.
In total, we have obtained 95,803 output tuples along with their provenance expressions (computed with ProvSQL).

We saw in Section 6.2 that the inexact method CNF Proxy is very efficient and that the ranking of tuples based on CNF Proxy is typically close to the ranking obtained based on the real Shapley values.
Our practical implementation is currently designed for SPJU queries (that is, to the class of queries supported by ProvSQL).

In this section we propose CNF Proxy, a heuristic solution that is very efficient, and we will experimentally show that the ranking of facts based on CNF Proxy tends to match the ranking based on the exact Shapley values.

Figure 7d zooms in on the aggregated results over the worst case ex- pressions of all output tuples for all queries, and shows that even the worst case CNF Proxy is superior to the alternatives, and that the error in terms of nDCG is small (0.92 in the worst case evaluated).
First, we have measured (in the column "Execution time") the execution time in PostgreSQL, which includes provenance generation for every out- put tuple using ProvSQL.

The computation of Shapley values (KC plus Algo- rithm 1) takes 27,600 seconds if performed for all output tuples of query q8d in the IMDB dataset; for comparison, the CNF Proxy method has (inexactly, see quality analysis below) computed the Shapley value of the proxy functions for all query outputs within 95 seconds, which is 0.3% of the exact computation time.

Both Monte Carlo and Kernel SHAP suffer from a massive drop of median (resp., mean) Precision@10, down to 0.4 (resp., 0.476) and 0.6 (resp., 0.6253) respectively with 201-400 facts, while CNF Proxy remains at 0.8 (resp., 0.8293) median and mean Precision@10.

Since no standard benchmark for our problem exists, we have created such a benchmark of 40 queries over the TPC-H (1.4GB) and IMDB (1.2GB) databases.The TPC-H queries are based on the ones in [34], where we have only removed nested queries (which ProvSQL does not handle) and aggregation operations (for which provenance is not Boolean).
